sourceDesc.p:
This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed REED collections - Inns of Court, Ecclesiastical London, and Civic London to 1558. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
Ecclesiastical London
Mary C. Erler
University of Toronto Press and The British Library. 2008
504
978-0-8020-9858-0 978-0-7123-5024-2

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

REED London Online is a prototype online collection developing from the Records of Early English Drama (REED) in partnership with the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC) and supported by Bucknell University. It aims to establish an openly accessible online scholarly and pedagogical resource of London-centric documentary, editorial, and bibliographic materials related to performance, theatre, and music spanning the period 1100-1642. With support from an NHPRC-Mellon Planning Grant for Digital Edition Publishing Cooperatives and CANARIE Research Software Program grants, REED London is creating new environments for scholarly presentation of archival materials gathered from legal, ecclesiastical, civic, political, and personal archival sources in and around London. The objective of the REED London project team is to build a stable, extensible publication environment that optimizes access to these compiled materials in ways that respond to scholars’ research interests across disciplines. Consulting with other planning grant recipients will be invaluable to ensuring that REED London’s production and publication environment is in line with standards laid out in the NHPRC-Mellon grant objectives. It is hoped that the progress REED London and CWRC make will also inform the larger dialogue about best practices among funded teams.

row.cell: Item to the MynstrellesMynstrelles: for the feast time
Item to the MynstrellesMynstrelles: for the feast time
Item the MynstrellesMynstrelles: for the feast time

div.label: (16 September–16 September) (Payments first at supper) (REED: Civic)

row.cell: Item the MynstrellesMynstrelles: for the feast time
Item paid for the standyng of our Compeignyg and pavyng of the ground
Item the MynstrellesMynstrelles: for the feast time
Item the MynstrellesMynstrelles: for the feast time
Item paid for xvj yerdes whytt cottyn for watche mene at mydsomer
Item pid for makyng off iiij cottes
Item paid to the mynstrallesMynstrelles: for 15 December

div.label: Endnote
div.p: The manuscript heading (p 93) specifies taht the dinner was 'mayd' by the three wardens on the Sunday after the Conception of Our Lady in 2 Henry VIII (that is, on 15 December 1510), who also on this occasion distributed blue livery. Although 15 December is well past what appears to be the company's normal August/September (perhaps even October) feast time (see The Documents, p. xcviii), the accounting span this year unusually runs from 1509 to January 1510/11, so the mass, dinner, and minstrels here are indeed presumably at the annual feast time.

row.cell: Item fore MynstrellsMynstrelles: for the feast time

div.label: Endnote
div.p: During this irregularly long accounting span (almost two years, and not according to the company's usual dates), this feast-time supper could be in 1511 or in 1512, if held independently of the accounting span. It is probably in 1512, however, since the account ends in that year and does not include two suppers or dinners. For the Founders' feast time, see The Documents, p xcviii.

div.label: (24 October––18 October) (Costs of your dinner, 27 September)

row.cell: Item payd the MynstrellsMynstrelles: for the feast time

div.label: (18 October––15 October) (Costs of your supper 20 August)

row.cell: Item payd the MynstrellsMynstrelles: for the feast time
Item payd at mydsomer for viij Ȝerdes of whyȜt Cottyn pris

div.label: Endnote
div.p: The account span must be deduced from the surrounding accounts, the datings of which are also problematic, but the preceding account (which has a self-contradictory dating) can be worked out as for 1520–1 (ending 23 October), and the following account, as for 1522–3. The wardens named in the main account heading, as in their first year, are those named as incoming at the end of the preceding (1520–1) account. The only date on this 1521–2 account is 32 September, with no calendar year(s) or regnal year(s) supplied; the date is an error for 22 or 23 September (as a closing date), as 32 cannot refer either to the calendar year or to the regnal year (September 1522 would be 14 Henry VIII), and '33' September is given as a closing or audit date on p 195. On p 194 appears what seems to be another version of the record on p 190 (both are from the same account), and so it has not been transcribed and included here, although it is possible that the company bought two lots of white cotton.

div.label: (18 October––19 October) (Costs of your dinner 26 August)

row.cell: Item payd the MynstrellsMynstrelles: for the feast time
Item ffor A menstrellMynstrelles: for the feast time

div.label: Endnote
div.p: No opening or closing month is given in the heading of the preceding account, but internal evidence shows that this account begins in October.

row.cell: Item payd for A menstrellmenstrell: for the feast time
Item payd for A menstrellmenstrell: for the feast time
Item paid for ix yerdes of cotton
Item paid for a quere of paper
Item paid for makyng of ij cottes
Item paid for ij allmayn Revettes
pai to ij men In þe mayers wache saynt Iohns nyght & saynt peturs nyght
Item paid to þe playersmynstrelles, players: for the feast time
paid to ij mene at mydesumer þat bare þe Cresetes & one þat bare þe lyghtes
Item to ij mene þat bare bowys
paid for Creset lyghtes þe stone ij d. ob.
paid to ij mene at mydseumer þat bare þe Cresetes & one þa bare þe lyghtes
Item to ij mene þat bare bowys
paid for Creset lyghtes þe stone ij d. ob.
paid for a C wayte of Cresset lyghtes
paid to ij mene þat bare þe Cressetes & on þat bare þe bage
paid to ij mene with bowys

div.ab: Thes be þe Chargys of þe barge at þe tryommffe of quene kateryn

row.cell: Item for a grene ffysshe a goyle of sale sawmond & for a habredyne
Item paid for hyere of þe barge
Item paid for roweres & sterys man
Item paid for þe hyere of an ynsterment
Item paid In drynking money to þe rowyers
Item paid to þe Clarke for playeng of þe ynsterment

div.label: Endnote
div.p: The account heading wrongly gives the account's closing year as 30 Henry VIII (that is, 1538); the closing statement by the auditors gives the clearly correct year, 33 Henry VIII (taht is, 1541). The preceding account closes 11 October 1540 and the following account opens 19 October 1541. The 'tryommffe' of Katherine Howard is the city's escorting of her and Henry VIII by water to Greenwich on 19 March; see Appendix 1.

row.cell: paid for iij quarterns of C of Cressetes lyght
paid for mendyng þe halle be syde þe Coberd
paid to iij mene at mydesomer ij with Cressetes & one þat bare þe lyghtes
for ij þat bare þe Cressetes
for on þat bare þe bage with lyghtes
Receiuid of players for playing in the hall
>Receiuid of players for playing in the hall

div.label: Endnote
div.p: The original manuscript headings are receipts of Mr Bere (p 308) and receipts of Mr Taylor (p 311). John Bere (Beer, Beers, etc; see Parsloe, Founders, p 455) was company master in 1543–4. Roger Taylor was one of the company wardens in 1543–4 (see Parsloe, Founders, p 487).

row.cell: Item Receiuid for playing in the hall from seynt Nycholas day tyll after chrystmas
Receiuid of a gentyllman for makyng pastyme in ye hall

div.head: Endnote
div.p: The heading in the manuscript is Mr White’s receipts; Humphrey Whyte (White, etc; see Parsloe, Founders, p 490) was company master in 1544–5. The ‘playing’ and/or the ‘pastyme’ need not have been theatrical; but elsewhere in the Founders’ early accounts there are receipts from players (Founders' Wardens' Accounts, 1543–4) and a play (Founders' Wardens' Accounts, 1546–7).

row.cell: Receiued for a pllay in ye all
paid to ye kynges magestye for a fyftyne & a hallfe

div.head: Endnote
div.p: The manuscript heading for the p 323 transcription is the receipts of Mr Abbott. William Abbott (Abbot, etc; see Parsloe, Founders, p 452) was company master in 1546–8.

The fifteenth and a half recorded on p 324 is presumably for the city’s costs for the funeral of Henry VIII and coronation of Edward VI; see Journal 15, 1546–7, ff 303v–4 and 304v. The amount of 3s was also what was paid by the company for the one-and-a-half fifteenths assessed for the entry of Philip of Spain in 1554 (Founders' Wardens' Accounts, 1553–4). For the wording implying a payment to the king rather than to the city, see Lancashire (ed), Civic London to 1558, pp cxxvi–cxxvii. The transcribed payment is followed by the costs of a frame for the company to stand in when the king came through London to his coronation.

row.cell: Receiuid of players for playing in the hall
Receiuid of playars for playing in the hall

div.head: Endnote
div.p: The original manuscript headings are receipts of Mr Bere (p 308) and receipts of Mr Taylor (p 311). John Bere (Beer, Beers, etc; see Parsloe, Founders, p 455) was company master in 1543–4. Roger Taylor was one of the company wardens in 1543–4 (see Parsloe, Founders, p 487).

row.cell: Receiuid for playinges & weddinges in the hall with the watterbearers feast

div.head: Endnote
div.p: The manuscript heading is Mr Whyte’s receipts. Humphrey Whyte (White, etc; see Parsloe, Founders, p 490) was company master in 1548–9. These ‘playinges’ need not have been theatrical; but elsewhere in the Founders’ early accounts there are receipts from players (Founders' Wardens' Accounts, 1543–4), and a play (Founders' Wardens' Accounts, 1546–7). Parsloe notes, p 111, that the Waterbearers held their feast in Founders’ Hall in all of 1545–6, 1548–9, and 1550–1.

row.cell: Item for a xv & a hallfe for the hall

div.head: Endnote
div.p: For common council’s approval of a fifteenth and a half for the costs of pageants, etc, for the royal entry of Philip of Spain, see Journal 16, 1553–4, f 289.

head.title: Founders’ Company Wardens’ Accounts, October 1558-October 1559 (Hill Draft)

row.cell: paide to the bargemen for hyer of a barge the xij daye of ?Janiver to the companye at the quenes comynge frome Westmynster
payde to John nycolles and his fellowe for a subsedie granted to the quene
payde for a fyften for the hall in October for the use of quene marye
paide for settynge up the Rayle at the comynge in of quene elyzabeth
payde for makynge up the clothe yt laye on ye rayles
payde to the Watermen for a Rewarde when the quene came from Westmynster
paide for Lyne and pacthred the same tyme
payde for Carying the instrumentes and ?home agayne
payde to the syngynge men in ye Barge
payde for the barge men and syngners brekfast
payde for iij whyte staves for wyflers
payde for settyng up the standying and for the Caryage that same daye
payde for makynge up the clothe & cariage
payde Mr Awncyll and Mr shorbucke for ij fyfteenes grawntyd to the Citie
Payd to the paynter ffor payntyng the kinges armes
Payde ffor iij staves ffor Wefflers when the quyne went a ? and cam throw the Citie ——— }
